Zan among the trigrams represents thunder, and, according to Wan’s arrangement and significance of them, ‘ the oldest son.’ It is a phonetic character in which the significant constituent is Yu, meaning rain, and with which are formed most characters that denote atmospherical phenomena. The hexagram is formed of the trigram Zhn redoubled, and may be taken as representing the crash or peal of thunder; but we have seen that the attribute or virtue of the trigram is 'moving, exciting power;’ and thence, symbolically, the character is indicative of movement taking place in society or in the kingdom. This is the meaning of the hexagram; and the subject is the conduct to be pursued in a time of movement—such as insurrection or revolution—by the party promoting, and most interested in, the situation. It is shown how he ought to be aware of the dangers of the time, and how by precaution and the regula tion of himself he may overcome them, The indication of a successful issue given by the figure is sup posed to be given by the undivided line at the bottom of the trigram. Mountains rise up grandly from the surface of the earth, and their masses rest on it in quiet and solemn majesty; and they serve also to arrest the on ward progress of the traveller. Hence the attribute ascribed to Kan is twofold; it is both active and passive—resting and arresting. The character is used in this hexagram with both of those signifi cations. As the name of the figure, it denotes the mental charac teristic of resting in what is right; especially resting, as it is expressed by Chinese critics, ‘ in principle,'—that which is right, on the widest scale, and in the absolute conception of the mind; and that which is right in every different position in which a man can be placed. We find this treated of in the Great Learning (Commentary, chapter 3), and in the Doctrine of the Mean, chapter 14, and other places. This is the theme of the hexa gram ; and the symbolism of it is all taken from different parts of the human body, as in hexagram 31, and the way in which they are dealt with. Several of the paragraphs are certainly not easy to translate and interpret. The other parts of the body, such as the mouth, eyes, and ears, have their appetencies, which lead them to what is without them selves. The back alone has nothing to do with anything beyond itself—hardly with itself even; all that it has to do is to stand straight and strong. So should it he with us, resting in principle, free from the intrusion of selfish thoughts and external objects. Amidst society, he who realises the idea of the hexagram is still alone, and does not allow himself to be distracted from the con templation and following of principle. He is not a recluse, how ever, who keeps aloof from social life; but his distinction is that he maintains a supreme regard to principle, when alone, and when mingling with others. In the symbolism the author rises from one part of the body to the other. The first line at the bottom of the figure fitly suggests ‘ the toes.' The lesson is that from the first men should rest in, and be anxious to do, what is right in all their affairs. core_meaning.normalized_summary: Sudden shock, like thunder. A jolt hits: fear, adrenaline, chaos. The teaching is not ‘don’t be afraid’ — it’s ‘stay composed in the fear.’ Even when events shake the world, you keep your role, your ritual, your duty. Panic scatters you; disciplined steadiness carries you through danger without losing what matters.

lines.normalized_meaning: The first hit of shock startles you — totally natural. But you regain composure and even laugh. Courage isn’t absence of fear; it’s recovery after fear. That’s auspicious.

lines.normalized_meaning: Crisis hits and you drop valuables to get to safety fast. Don’t cling to possessions or status in the moment of shock. If you get clear and survive, what’s truly yours returns in time.

lines.normalized_meaning: You’re shaken, anxious, maybe trembling — but if you channel that state into appropriate, constructive action instead of panic, you avoid blame and harm.

lines.normalized_meaning: Instead of responding, you go limp and bog down. Shock turns into paralysis. This is the danger of letting fear turn you passive — you get dragged into the mud.

lines.normalized_meaning: You’re moving through danger constantly — back and forth in the storm — but you’re still functional. You may keep what matters and even find meaningful work to do in the midst of chaos.
